question: Between the head coach of a small Catholic college basketball programme in the New York metropolitan area and the coach who took over a Big 12 programme in Iowa after leaving a mid-major school in Kentucky, which one has held their current position for longer?
llm_answer: The head coach of the small Catholic college basketball programme in the New York metropolitan area, Tim Cluess, has held his current position for longer.

context.text: The 2015–16 Iowa State Cyclones men's basketball team represented Iowa State University during the 2015–16 NCAA Division I men's basketball season . The Cyclones were coached by Steve Prohm , who was in his 1st season. They played their home games at Hilton Coliseum in Ames, Iowa and competed in the Big 12 Conference . They finished the season 23–12 10–8 in Big 12 play to finish tied for 5th place. They lost to Oklahoma in the quarterfinals of the Big 12 Conference tournament . They received an at-large bid to the NCAA tournament where they defeated Iona and Little Rock to advance to the Sweet Sixteen where they lost to Virginia . Previous season Iowa State finished the season 25–9, 12–6 in Big 12 play to finish in second place. They defeated Texas , Oklahoma , and Kansas to become champions of the Big 12 Conference tournament to earn and automatic bid to the NCAA tournament . In the NCAA Tournament they were upset by UAB in the second round. After months of speculation, it was announced on June 2, 2015, that Fred Hoiberg would be accepting the head coach position with the Chicago Bulls of the NBA . On June 8, 2015, it was announced that Iowa State would be hiring Murray State head coach Steve Prohm for the same position. Offseason departures Recruiting Prep recruits Incoming transfers Roster Schedule and results Rankings Awards and honors References

Daniel S. Hurley (born January 16, 1973) is an American men's college basketball coach who is the head coach of the UConn Huskies . In 2023 and 2024, Hurley led UConn to back-to-back NCAA Division I national championships . He previously coached at Rhode Island and Wagner . Throughout his career, Hurley has been known for his intensity and enthusiasm. His high level of passion on the sidelines and heated interactions with referees became defining aspects of his coaching style. Early life and education Hurley was born to Hall of Fame high school coach Bob Hurley Sr. and Christine Hurley on January 16, 1973, in Jersey City, New Jersey , where he was raised with his siblings Bobby and Melissa. Bobby is a former Duke and Sacramento Kings guard and the current head coach at Arizona State. Hurley was a basketball star at St. Anthony High School in Jersey City, where his father was the longtime coach. He led the team to a 31–1 record and a No. 2 national ranking as a senior. He played five years of college basketball, including a redshirt year, at Seton Hall . He played under head coach P. J. Carlesimo during his first three seasons. Career Hurley was head coach of Saint Benedict's Preparatory School (2001–2010), where he is credited with building the New Jersey school into one of the top high school basketball programs in America. He was the head coach at Wagner College for two years (2010–2012), where he set the school single-season win-loss record at 25–6 during the 2011–2012 season. He was then head coach at the University of Rhode Island for six years (2012–2018), bringing the team to the 2017 and 2018 NCAA tournaments, the first times since 1999. Hurley turned down a long-term offer from Rhode Island in order to lead the University of Connecticut Huskies . Hurley during a 2023 departure ceremony for the NCAA Final Four From 2010 to 2013, his brother Bobby was one of his assistant coaches at both Rhode Island and Wagner. University of Connecticut He was named head coach of UConn on March 22, 2018. In 2021, he returned the Huskies to the NCAA tournament for the first time since 2016, then again in 2022, losing in the first round both times. He won the NCAA championship with the Huskies in 2023. In June 2023, he agreed to a six-year contract extension with UConn worth $32.1M. In July 2024, he signed an extension worth $50M over six years. In the 2023–24 season, Hurley led the Huskies to a school-record 37 wins, a Big East regular season title, a Big East

Robert Emmet Hurley (born July 31, 1947) is an American basketball coach. At the now-closed St. Anthony High School in Jersey City, New Jersey , Hurley amassed 26 state championships in 39 years as a coach. On February 2, 2011, Hurley became the tenth coach in high school history to win 1,000 games. Five of his teams have gone undefeated. On April 5, 2010, he was announced as the only coach to be inducted into the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame that year and only the third high school coach in history to be so honored; he was formally inducted on August 13 of that year. Hurley is the father of Bobby Hurley , an All-American point guard who won two national championships at Duke and the head basketball coach at Arizona State , and Dan Hurley , who has won back to back national championships ('23-'24) as the head coach of the University of Connecticut . Biography Early life Hurley was born and raised in the Greenville section of Jersey City and grew up in St. Paul parish, in an era when neighborhoods identified with their parishes, later attending St. Peter's Preparatory School . His father was a police officer. Hurley attended St. Peter's College , but was cut from the varsity basketball team in his sophomore year. He began volunteering as a coach for a Catholic Youth Organization grammar school team in his parish. Career Hurley began coaching at St. Anthony in 1967. The school, run by Felician Sisters , had one of New Jersey's smallest student bodies, most of whom lived below or near the poverty line during the latter portion of Hurley's career. Hurley produced over 150 players to Division I basketball programs, all on full scholarships. Hurley has coached six first-round NBA draft picks, including his own son, Bobby Hurley. Hurley's undefeated 1989 team, which featured Jerry Walker, Hurley's son Bobby, Terry Dehere , and Rodrick Rhodes , was ranked first in the nation by USA Today . Three of the players on that team – Bobby Hurley, Dehere and Rhodes – were first-round choices in the NBA draft. That team won New Jersey's first Tournament of Champions and amassed 50 straight victories in a two-year span. It is generally considered one of the best teams in American history. Hurley has also produced a total of six first-round NBA draft picks: his son Bobby, Dehere, Rhodes, David Rivers , Roshown McLeod and Kyle Anderson . Hurley's 2003–04 team, also undefeated and ranked second in the nation, is the subject of The Miracle of St. Anthony , a best-selling book by Adrian Wojnarowski . The book chronicles how the team marched to an unbeaten season, state title, and number 2 national ranking despite off-the-court crises and not having a

Robert M. Hurley (born June 28, 1971) is an American college basketball coach and former professional player who is the head coach of the Arizona State Sun Devils . He was previously the head coach at the University at Buffalo . As a college senior, he was a unanimous first-team All-America for the Duke Blue Devils , with whom he won consecutive national championships. He is the all-time leader in assists in NCAA basketball. He played in the National Basketball Association (NBA) for the Sacramento Kings and Vancouver Grizzlies from 1993 to 1999. Early life Hurley was born to Bob Hurley Sr. and Christine Hurley on June 28, 1971, in Jersey City, New Jersey , where he was raised with his siblings Dan and Melissa. Hurley attended Our Lady of Mercy grammar school in Jersey City. Playing career Hurley in high school, circa 1988 Hurley was a basketball star at St. Anthony High School in Jersey City, where his father was the longtime coach. While at St. Anthony from 1985 to 1989, Hurley led the team to four consecutive Parochial B state titles. In his senior year he averaged 20 points, 8 assists and 3 steals, as St. Anthony racked up a 32–0 record, the school's first Tournament of champions crown, and the No. 1 ranking in the United States. In his high school career the team's overall record with Hurley as point guard was 115–5. Duke Hurley was a point guard for coach Mike Krzyzewski 's Duke University team from 1989 to 1993. He was a first-team All-America in 1993, went to the Final Four three times, and helped lead the Blue Devils to back-to-back national championships in 1991 and 1992 with All American teammates Christian Laettner and Grant Hill , earning Final Four Most Outstanding Player honors in 1992. Hurley remains the NCAA all-time assists leader with 1076 assists, and Duke's single game assist leader with 16 (against Florida State on February 24, 1993). His Duke jersey number 11 was retired in 1993. In 2002, Hurley was named to the ACC 50th Anniversary men's basketball team as one of the fifty greatest players in Atlantic Coast Conference history. In 2006, Hurley, who is of Polish descent through his mother, was inducted into the National Polish American Sports Hall of Fame. At Duke, Hurley was a member of the Sigma Phi Epsilon fraternity. Coincidentally, Bobby Hurley played against his younger brother Dan in an NCAA Tournament game, when Duke squared off against Seton Hall. Hurley appeared in the 1994 feature film Blue Chips , where he played for the Indiana team under coach Bobby Knight . NBA Hurley was selected by the Sacramento Kings as the seventh

the Cougars left the WAC in 1999, the rivalry with Fresno State has increased greatly in recent years, with both teams being the oldest members of the WAC contending regularly for the conference championship. Coaches from both schools have accused each side of various episodes of poor sportsmanship over the years, and both schools have some of the nation's rowdiest home fans. The rivalry has featured some lopsided results, including a 70–14 Fresno victory over Hawaiʻi in 2004 and a 68–37 Warriors victory in 2006 over Fresno . In 2007 , allegations that Fresno State fans were physically and verbally abused by hometown Hawaiʻi fans circulated the internet and television media added to this rivalry. It was being reported that several Fresno State fans attempted to warn Boise State fans from attending Hawaiʻi football games due to potential violence against them, however no incidents were reported by Boise State fans and many photographs from Hawaiʻi-based publications covered incidents where Hawaiʻi and Boise State fans were seen mingling together before and after their 2007 game. The rivalry still continues to be one that is anticipated by both sides and continues to the present, with Fresno State having joined the Mountain West Conference in 2012, reuniting it with Hawaiʻi and other former WAC members in Nevada and Boise State. It is Hawaii's most-played rivalry series. The two teams have met 57 times, with Fresno State leading the all-time series 31–25–1. Air Force Battle for the Kuter Trophy This is one of the oldest rivalries involving Hawaii, along with the Fresno State rivalry. This rivalry is attributed to the late General Laurence S. Kuter, who was stationed on Joint Base Pearl Harbor-Hickam as commander of the Pacific Air Forces. This led to the creation of the Kuter Trophy, a symbol of sportsmanship and school pride, but also the eternal friendship between the Air Force and Hawaii. Hawaii is in possession of the trophy following their 44–35 in Colorado Springs in 2025. The two teams have met 24 times, with Air Force leading the series 14–9–1. Wyoming Battle for the Paniolo Trophy The rivalry began in 1978, when Hawaii joined the Western Athletic Conference , and was played annually until 1997, shortly before Wyoming departed from the WAC and joined the newly formed Mountain West Conference . The rivalry was renewed in 2013 when Hawaii joined the MW as a football-only affiliate member. The teams have met 29 times, with Wyoming leading the series 17–12. Wyoming and Hawaii play for the Paniolo Trophy. 'Paniolo' is a Hawaiian word meaning “ cowboy ”, and the trophy featured a bronze cowboy on horseback, twirling a lariat . The trophy was donated to the two schools by the Wyoming Paniolo Society, a group of Hawaii

worth $32.1M. In July 2024, he signed an extension worth $50M over six years. In the 2023–24 season, Hurley led the Huskies to a school-record 37 wins, a Big East regular season title, a Big East tournament championship, a #1 overall seed in the NCAA tournament for the first time in school history, and a second-straight NCAA national championship. He was named the Naismith College Coach of the Year and received the Sporting News National Coach of the Year Award . In the days after winning the 2024 Final Four, Hurley received and declined a lucrative head coaching offer from Kentucky . In June 2024 he interviewed with the Los Angeles Lakers , but declined their offer as well, choosing to return to UConn to attempt to win a third straight championship. Personal life Hurley married Andrea Sirakides in 1997. They met while they were both students at Seton Hall. They have two sons: Danny (born July, 1999) and Andrew (born January 30, 2002). Danny graduated from Seton Hall in 2021. Andrew attends the University of Connecticut, where he was on his father's 2023 and 2024 NCAA championship teams. On September 6, 2019, Hurley had surgery to replace two disks in his neck with artificial ones. Doctors told Hurley the condition was part hereditary and part the result of years of wear and tear associated with being a lifelong athlete. He returned to work less than two weeks after surgery. Hurley is a practicing Catholic. During his years at Seton Hall, Hurley met psychologist Sister Catherine Waters, who changed his life. He often talks with and thanks Sr. Catherine, even after his NCAA championship in 2023. He is an avid fan of the Cincinnati Bengals . Head coaching record References External links Connecticut profile

Previously tied with Tom Dempsey and Sebastian Janikowski for the longest field goal in NFL history (63 yards). Abe Elimimian – former Hawaiʻi cornerback (2000–2004). Current Hawaii assistant coach (2015–present).

Allison Thomas Stanislaus " Pooley " Hubert (April 6, 1901 – February 26, 1978) was an American football player and coach of football and basketball . Regarded as one of the South 's greatest college football stars, he played quarterback for coach Wallace Wade 's football teams at the University of Alabama from 1922 to 1925, leading Alabama to its first bowl game , the 1926 Rose Bowl , known as "the game that changed the South." Wade called him "undoubtedly one of the greatest football players of all time." Hubert later became the head football and basketball coach at the Mississippi State Teachers College—now known as University of Southern Mississippi —and Virginia Military Institute . He was inducted into the College Football Hall of Fame as a player in 1964. Early years Pooley dropped out of high school to fight in World War I . He attended Missouri Military Academy in Mexico, Missouri , where he played football in the fall of 1920. Pooley earned a scholarship to play football at Princeton University , but arrived too late for the entrance exams. He tried a few other schools including Georgia Tech , for which he was one day late, before ultimately enrolling at the University of Alabama as a 20-year-old freshman. University of Alabama Pooley initially played tackle in college, but was eventually put in the backfield where he excelled at fullback and quarterback . In those days of one-platoon football, players played on both offense, defense, and special teams. Not only was Hubert his team's best passer ; he was also called the "greatest defensive back of all time." He wore number 10. He stood 5'10" and 190 pounds. In six different games he scored at least three touchdowns, and had 35 in all. Zipp Newman wrote "No player deserves more credit for getting Alabama started up the ladder than Hubert—a football coach on the field. He wasn't fast, but he could pass, punt, buck for short yardage, and inspired his teammates. There have been few field generals in Pooley's class." Herman Stegeman remarked that with Hubert in the game Alabama had the advantage another team would have by a coach on the field of play. 1924 Pooley was captain of the 1924 team which netted Alabama's first conference championship, as members of the Southern Conference . It suffered a lone upset to Herb Covington -led Centre . Hubert scored in the 14–0 win over Sewanee . In the 20–0 win over Furman, Hubert scored twice, once on a 4-yard run and next on a 35-yard off-tackle run . He threw two touchdowns in the win over Georgia to secure the conference. At year's end Hubert was chosen for the composite All-Southern team. Alabama's first Rose Bowl touchdown. Hubert is

The 2015–16 Iona Gaels men's basketball team represented Iona College during the 2015–16 NCAA Division I men's basketball season . The Gaels, led by sixth year head coach Tim Cluess , played their home games at the Hynes Athletic Center and were members of the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference (MAAC). They finished the season 22–11, 16–4 in MAAC play to finish in second place. They defeated Canisius , Siena , and Monmouth to be champions of the MAAC tournament and earn the conference's automatic bid to the NCAA tournament where, as a #13 seed, they lost in the first round to Iowa State . Previous season The Gaels finished the 2014–15 season 26–9, 17–3 in MAAC play to win the MAAC regular season championship. Iona lost to Manhattan in the championship game of the MAAC tournament and earned an automatic bid to the National Invitation Tournament . In the NIT, they lost in the first round to Rhode Island . Roster Schedule References

Hawaii play for the Paniolo Trophy. 'Paniolo' is a Hawaiian word meaning “ cowboy ”, and the trophy featured a bronze cowboy on horseback, twirling a lariat . The trophy was donated to the two schools by the Wyoming Paniolo Society, a group of Hawaii residents with Wyoming roots. Because the two teams could not find the original trophy, a new trophy was modeled after a statue that stands in Waimea on the Big Island at the Parker Ranch Center. Wyoming won that game in Laramie 59–56 in overtime. Before that, the last time the two schools met was in 1997 in the old Western Athletic Conference with Wyoming winning 35–6 in Honolulu. Hawaii holds the Paniolo Trophy as they won the most recent meeting, 27–7 in Honolulu. San Jose State Dick Tomey Legacy Game The two schools were each led by legendary coach Dick Tomey, who died in 2019. The winner of the rivalry game each year takes possession of the Dick Tomey Legacy Trophy. San Jose State currently holds the trophy after winning the last 5 meetings, the most recent in San Jose in 2025. The two schools first met in 1936. The Rainbow Warriors and Spartans have played each other 47 times. The Spartans lead the series 24–22–1. UNLV Ninth Island Showdown Beginning in 2017, the annual game between UNLV and Hawai'i , Ninth Island Showdown or, The Battle for the Golden Pineapple gained a rivalry trophy when the California Hotel and Casino donated the "Golden Pineapple" to the winner of the game. Las Vegas, Nevada has long been a popular destination for Hawaiians for both pleasure and relocation, so much so that it has been dubbed "the Ninth Island", with the Cal Hotel in particular aggressively marketing itself to Hawaiian tourists. UNLV is one of Hawaii's two protected Mountain West Conference rivalries when the conference shifts to one division in 2023, meaning they will play every year. The 'Bows lead the all-time series between the two schools 19–16. BYU Hawaii has a historic rivalry with the BYU Cougars. Both were members of the WAC from 1979 to 1998. BYU operates a satellite campus in Laie, Hawaii and there are a large number of LDS church members in the state. As well, both schools have a significant number of Polynesian descent players. In 1990, Hawaii upset #4 ranked BYU and Heisman trophy winner, Ty Detmer, 59–28. In 2001, Hawaii upset undefeated #9 BYU, 72–45. In 2019, Hawaii defeated BYU in the Hawaii Bowl, 38–34. Stadiums Aloha Stadium was the Warriors former home for over 4 decades Moiliili Field (1909–1926) Honolulu Stadium (1926–1974) Aloha Stadium

communities.summary:
**Title**: 2015–16 Iowa State Cyclones Season  

**Summary**:  
The 2015–16 Iowa State Cyclones men’s basketball team, led by first-year head coach Steve Prohm, posted a 23–12 record and reached the NCAA Sweet Sixteen after wins over Iona and Little Rock. Finishing fifth in the Big 12 at 10–8, they bowed out to Oklahoma in the conference-tournament quarterfinals before earning an at-large NCAA bid. The season followed a 2014–15 campaign in which Iowa State won the Big 12 tournament under Fred Hoiberg, who left for the Chicago Bulls in June 2015, prompting the hiring of Prohm from Murray State.  

**Keywords**:  
Iowa State Cyclones, Steve Prohm, 2015–16 season, NCAA Sweet Sixteen, Big 12 Conference

**Title**: Dan Hurley Coaching Career

**Summary**: Dan Hurley, born in 1973 to Hall-of-Fame high-school coach Bob Hurley Sr., built a decorated basketball résumé from St. Anthony HS standout to Seton Hall guard. After transforming St. Benedict’s Prep into a national powerhouse, he set Wagner’s single-season wins record, revived Rhode Island with two NCAA-tournament berths, and since 2018 has led UConn to back-to-back national titles (2023, 2024), a 37-win school record, and his own Naismith Coach-of-the-Year honors. Known for intense sideline energy, Hurley turned down lucrative offers from Kentucky and the Los Angeles Lakers in 2024, staying at UConn to pursue a third straight championship while guiding son Andrew on the roster.

**Keywords**: UConn basketball, NCAA championships, Dan Hurley, college coaching, Big East

**Title**: Tim Esmay Coaching Career

**Summary**: Tim Esmay is an American baseball coach and former head coach of the Arizona State Sun Devils baseball team from 2010 to 2014. An Arizona State alumnus who played there from 1986–1987, Esmay served as an assistant coach at Arizona State, Grand Canyon, and Utah before becoming Utah's head coach from 1997–2004. He returned to Arizona State as an assistant under Pat Murphy from 2005–2009, then became interim head coach in 2010 after Murphy's resignation due to NCAA violations. After leading the team to the 2010 College World Series, he was officially named head coach, though the program faced postseason sanctions in 2012 due to Murphy's violations. Since 2024, Esmay has managed the Arizona Athletics of the Arizona Complex League.

**Keywords**: baseball coach, Arizona State, NCAA violations, College World Series, Arizona Athletics

**Title**: 2011–12 Murray State Racers Season  

**Summary**:  
The 2011–12 Murray State Racers men’s basketball team, coached by first-year head coach Steve Prohm, dominated the Ohio Valley Conference with a 31–2 record. They secured both the OVC regular-season and tournament titles, earning an automatic NCAA tournament bid for their 15th appearance. After a second-round win over Colorado State, their run ended with a third-round loss to Marquette. Notably, guard Dexter Fields sat out the season due to NCAA transfer rules.  

**Keywords**: Murray State, 2011–12 season, Ohio Valley Conference, NCAA tournament, Steve Prohm

**Title**: Bobby Hurley Basketball Journey

**Summary**:  
Bobby Hurley, born in 1971 in Jersey City, is the NCAA all-time assists leader and a two-time national champion at Duke under Coach K. Drafted 7th overall by the Sacramento Kings in 1993, his NBA career was derailed by a near-fatal car crash his rookie season; he later played briefly for Vancouver before retiring in 1999. Hurley transitioned to coaching, first as an assistant alongside brother Dan at Wagner and Rhode Island, then as head coach at Buffalo (first NCAA berth) and Arizona State (Pac-12 program resurgence). Off the court, he owned racehorse Songandaprayer, faced foreclosure on Devil Eleven Stables, and has a family with wife Leslie.

**Keywords**:  
Duke point guard, NCAA assists leader, NBA draft #7, Arizona State coach, thoroughbred owner

**Title**: Great Neck Village School  

**Summary**:  
Great Neck Village School is a small public alternative high school in Nassau County, New York, designed for grades 8-12 students who are academically at-risk or overwhelmed by larger comprehensive high schools. With enrollment capped at about 50, it offers an intimate, low-stress environment that integrates outdoor education, college-prep coursework, and special-education services; roughly half the students qualify for special-education support. The school maintains a low student-teacher ratio (≈7:1), fosters student-run media such as the newspaper *The Villager*, and counts actress Nikki Blonsky among its notable alumni.  

**Keywords**: alternative education, at-risk students, small class size, special education, Great Neck

**Title**: Jamal Alioui Football Career

**Summary**: Jamal Alioui, born in 1982 in France, is a former professional footballer and current assistant head coach of Ligue 1 club Lyon. He played primarily in Europe but also had stints in Asia and Africa, representing Morocco internationally, including as captain at the 2004 Olympics. After retiring in 2016 due to hip issues, Alioui transitioned into coaching, managing several French clubs and serving as assistant coach for Morocco’s U20 team before joining Lyon in 2024.

**Keywords**: Jamal Alioui, Lyon assistant coach, Morocco football, 2004 Olympics, French football

**Title**: Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Bamenda

**Summary**:  
The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Bamenda, created in 1970 and elevated to an archdiocese in 1982, serves as the metropolitan see for Cameroon's ecclesiastical province of Bamenda, overseeing the suffragan dioceses of Buéa, Kumbo, and Mamfe. Its 35 parishes are grouped into six deaneries, with St Joseph's Metropolitan Cathedral as the archbishop's seat and several historic parish churches and shrines marking missionary heritage. Leadership succession has included Archbishops Paul Verdzekov, Cornelius Fontem Esua, and the current Archbishop Andrew Nkea Fuanya. The diocese has been twinned with the Diocese of Portsmouth, England, since 1974 and supports educational institutions such as Sacred Heart College.

**Keywords**: Bamenda archdiocese, Cameroon Catholicism, metropolitan see, suffragan dioceses, Portsmouth twinning

**Title**: Skip Peete Coaching Career

**Summary**: Willie "Skip" Peete is a veteran NFL running backs coach currently with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, having previously held the same role with the Cowboys, Rams, Bears, and Raiders. Starting as a 1985 All-Big Eight wide receiver at Kansas, he transitioned to coaching in 1988 at Pittsburgh, mentoring future Hall of Famer Curtis Martin. Across college and pro stops, he developed standout runners—including Marion Barber’s 2007 Pro Bowl season and the Cowboys’ 4.8-yards-per-carry franchise record in 2009—and productive receivers like Charlie Garner’s 962/941 rushing-receiving 2002 campaign. His coaching lineage extends from his father Willie Sr., former Bears RB coach, to his brother, ex-NFL quarterback Rodney Peete.

**Keywords**: NFL running backs coach, Dallas Cowboys, Curtis Martin, Tampa Bay Buccaneers, Peete family

**Title**: 2006 Hawaii Warriors Season

**Summary**:  
The 2006 Hawaii Warriors football team achieved an 11-win season, tying the school record and finishing second in the WAC behind undefeated Boise State. Quarterback Colt Brennan set NCAA single-season records with 58 touchdown passes and a 185.96 efficiency rating, earning sixth in Heisman voting and WAC Offensive Player of the Year honors. The Warriors capped their historic season with a 41–24 Hawaii Bowl victory over Arizona State, while head coach June Jones was named WAC Coach of the Year and nine players earned All-WAC first-team recognition.

**Keywords**:  
Colt Brennan, Hawaii Bowl, WAC, June Jones, 11-win season

**Title**: NBL Canada All-Star Game

**Summary**: The NBL Canada All-Star Game is an annual exhibition event organized by the National Basketball League of Canada, first held in 2012. Initially featuring randomly divided teams led by captains, the format later shifted to division-based matchups between the Central and Atlantic Divisions. The 2014 edition introduced coach-voted player selections, and the game is part of a larger All-Star Weekend that includes the Three-Point Shootout and Slam Dunk Championship.

**Keywords**: NBL Canada, All-Star Game, exhibition, All-Star Weekend, basketball

**Title**: Bob Hurley’s St. Anthony Dynasty  

**Summary**:  
Legendary coach Bob Hurley built St. Anthony High School into a national powerhouse, capturing 26 state titles and five undefeated seasons in 39 years while sending every senior to a Division I scholarship. His 1989, 2003-04 and 2007-08 squads are regarded among the greatest in U.S. high-school history, chronicled in the book *The Miracle of St. Anthony* and the PBS documentary *The Street Stops Here*. Despite the school’s tiny, under-resourced enrollment, Hurley produced six NBA first-round picks and over 150 Division I players, all while working full-time as a probation officer and declining every college offer. Inducted into the Naismith Hall of Fame in 2010, he now extends his impact through the free Hurley Family Foundation clinics for Jersey City youth.  

**Keywords**: Bob Hurley, St. Anthony basketball, 26 state championships, undefeated seasons, Naismith Hall of Fame

**Title:** Hawaii Rainbow Warriors Football 2019–2023  

**Summary:**  
The 2019 season marked Hawaii’s most successful campaign in eight years, featuring a 10–5 record, a Mountain West division title, and a dramatic Hawaii Bowl win over BYU behind Cole McDonald’s 493-yard, 4-TD performance. Head coach Nick Rolovich earned Mountain West Coach of the Year honors before departing for Washington State, prompting the hiring of Todd Graham. Graham’s 2020 squad notched a third straight winning season and a New Mexico Bowl victory, but 2021 saw Aloha Stadium shuttered, forcing on-campus games and ending with Graham’s resignation amid player-mistreatment allegations. Timmy Chang, a former UH quarterback, took over in 2022; his first two seasons produced 3–10 and 5–8 records while the program coped with mass transfers and facility uncertainty. Throughout these years, Hawaii’s rivalries with Fresno State, Air Force, and Wyoming remained central, with trophies like the Golden Screwdriver, Kuter, and Paniolo at stake.

**Keywords:**  
Hawaii Rainbow Warriors, Nick Rolovich, Todd Graham, Timmy Chang, Mountain West Conference

**Title**: Pooley Hubert Football Legacy

**Summary**: Allison "Pooley" Hubert was a legendary University of Alabama quarterback (1922-1925) who led the Crimson Tide to its first bowl victory in the 1926 Rose Bowl, a game credited with transforming Southern football. A triple-threat star who played offense, defense, and special teams, Hubert scored 35 touchdowns and was hailed by coach Wallace Wade as one of the greatest players ever. After captaining Alabama’s first conference-championship team in 1924 and securing the 1925 national title, he enjoyed a long coaching career at Mississippi State Teachers College and VMI, compiling a 69-69-13 collegiate record before retiring to peach farming and high-school coaching.

**Keywords**: Pooley Hubert, Alabama football, 1926 Rose Bowl, college football Hall of Fame, Southern football history

**Title**: Theodore Shapiro Psychoanalyst Scholar

**Summary**: Theodore Shapiro is a prominent New York-based psychiatrist and psychoanalyst who spent his career at Weill Cornell Medical College and Payne Whitney Psychiatric Clinic, becoming professor emeritus of psychiatry and pediatrics. He directed Cornell’s child psychiatry division, edited the Journal of the American Psychoanalytic Association for a decade, and held faculty roles at Columbia’s psychoanalytic center and the New York Psychoanalytic Institute. Over six decades he has authored or edited at least nine books and roughly 150 articles, advancing psychoanalytic understanding of empathy, autism, language, and affect, and co-developing panic-focused psychodynamic psychotherapy.

**Keywords**: psychoanalysis, child psychiatry, Weill Cornell, empathy/autism research, panic-focused psychotherapy

**Title:** Hawaii Rainbow Warriors Football History  

**Summary:**  
The Hawaii Rainbow Warriors football program, representing the University of Hawaiʻi at Mānoa, has evolved from its 1909 debut as the “Fighting Deans” through multiple conference affiliations and identity changes. Key milestones include the 1920s “Wonder Teams,” WWII hiatus, 1979 Western Athletic Conference entry, and 2012 Mountain West membership. The team gained national prominence under coaches Dick Tomey, Bob Wagner, and June Jones, highlighted by the 2007 undefeated regular season, Sugar Bowl berth, and NCAA records set by quarterback Colt Brennan.  

**Keywords:**  
Rainbow Warriors, June Jones era, Colt Brennan, WAC/Mountain West, 2007 undefeated season

**Title**: 2012 Hawaii Warriors Football Season

**Summary**:  
The 2012 Hawaii Warriors football team, under first-year head coach Norm Chow, transitioned into the Mountain West Conference and ended the season with a 3–9 overall record and 1–7 in conference play, tying for ninth place. Chow, a native Hawaiian and former Utah offensive coordinator, replaced the retiring Greg McMackin and shifted the team’s offensive strategy from the run-and-shoot to a pro-style system. Home games were held at Aloha Stadium, and the schedule included matchups against USC, BYU, Boise State, and other Mountain West opponents.

**Keywords**: Hawaii Warriors, Norm Chow, Mountain West Conference, 2012 season, Aloha Stadium

**Title**: Great Neck Public Schools Overview

**Summary**: Great Neck Public Schools (Union Free School District 7) serves roughly 6,800 K-12 students across parts of Great Neck, North New Hyde Park, North Hills, and Manhasset Hills in Nassau County, Long Island. The district operates ten schools—three high schools (including one alternative), two middle schools, four elementary schools, and a nursery school—and maintained a 10.7:1 student-teacher ratio in 2015-16. A $234 million budget was approved in 2019, and the district ranks first in New York and third nationally according to 2020 Niche data, with 75% ELA and 78% math proficiency in 2017. Declining enrollment from the 1970s-1980s reduced the number of elementary schools from eleven to four.

**Keywords**: Great Neck schools, Nassau County district, student-teacher ratio, Niche rankings, budget

**Title:** Hawaii Rainbow Warriors Football Alumni  

**Summary:**  
The University of Hawai‘i Rainbow Warriors football program has produced a large, accomplished network of players and coaches who have gone on to successful NFL, CFL, and collegiate careers. Notable alumni include multiple Super Bowl champions (Jesse Sapolu, Maa Tanuvasa, Adrian Klemm, Jason Elam, Marcus Kemp), Pro Bowlers, and high NFL draft picks (Ashley Lelie, Jahlani Tavai, Travis LaBoy). Many former players—such as Timmy Chang, Nick Rolovich, Ken Niumatalolo, and Brian Smith—have returned to coaching, with several leading Division I programs or serving as coordinators. The list also highlights specialists like record-setting kicker Jason Elam and Pro Bowl punter Rigoberto Sanchez, underscoring the program’s breadth of talent across positions.  

**Keywords:**  
Hawaii football alumni, NFL Super Bowl champions, Rainbow Warriors coaches, NFL draft picks

**Title**: 2006 Hawaii Warriors Historic Season  

**Summary**:  
The 2006 Hawaii Warriors, led by quarterback Colt Brennan, produced one of the most prolific offensive seasons in college football history. Brennan shattered the NCAA single-season touchdown-pass record with 58 TDs and amassed 5,549 passing yards, joining an elite group of 5,000-yard/50-TD passers. Receiver Jason Rivers set bowl-game receiving marks while the offense topped national charts in total yards, passing, and scoring. The team rode a nine-game win streak, finished 11-3, matched the school victory record, and accepted an early Hawaii Bowl invitation where they capped the year by defeating Arizona State 41-24. Coach June Jones became Hawaii’s all-time winningest coach, and multiple Warriors earned weekly conference and national honors.  

**Keywords**: Colt Brennan, June Jones, NCAA records, Hawaii Bowl, 2006 season

**Title**: 2006 Hawaii Warriors Football Season

**Summary**:  
The 2006 Hawaii Warriors football team, led by record-setting quarterback Colt Brennan, achieved significant success both individually and as a team. Brennan earned numerous accolades, including WAC Offensive Player of the Year, Sammy Baugh Trophy, and multiple All-American honors. The team showcased a high-powered offense, with standout performances from players like Davone Bess and Nate Ilaoa. Despite narrow losses to ranked opponents like Alabama and Boise State, Hawaii secured key victories over UNLV, Eastern Illinois, Nevada, and Fresno State. Several players received All-WAC recognition, and multiple Warriors were selected in the 2007 NFL Draft.

**Keywords**:  
Colt Brennan, Hawaii Warriors, 2006 season, WAC awards, NFL draft

**Title**: Saddle Rock Elementary School

**Summary**: Saddle Rock Elementary is a K-5 public school in Great Neck, New York, within the Great Neck Union Free School District. It earned the U.S. Department of Education’s Blue Ribbon School Award of Excellence for 1993-94 and was featured in a 1952 Life Magazine photo essay. During 2007-08 it enrolled 503 students across six grades plus an ungraded program, achieving an 11.4:1 student-teacher ratio with 47.4 full-time-equivalent teachers.

**Keywords**: Great Neck, Blue Ribbon School, K-5, student-teacher ratio, Life Magazine

**Title**: 2015–16 Iona Gaels Season

**Summary**: The 2015–16 Iona Gaels men’s basketball team, coached by Tim Cluess, posted a 22–11 record and captured the MAAC tournament title by defeating Canisius, Siena, and Monmouth, earning an automatic NCAA bid as a #13 seed before falling to Iowa State in the first round. After winning the MAAC regular-season crown the previous year but missing the NCAA tournament, the Gaels rebounded to secure the conference championship and return to March Madness. Home games were played at the Hynes Athletic Center.

**Keywords**: Iona Gaels, MAAC tournament, Tim Cluess, NCAA bid, 2015–16 season

**Title**: West Alabama Tigers Football Legacy

**Summary**:  
The West Alabama Tigers football program experienced a resurgence under coach Bobby Wallace, highlighted by dramatic wins like the 2009 overtime upset of #1 North Alabama and Wallace’s emotional 2010 finale victory over #7 Valdosta State. Success continued under Will Hall, who led back-to-back Gulf South Conference titles in 2012–13 and the school’s first NCAA Division II playoff wins. After Hall’s departure, the program navigated coaching transitions—Brett Gilliland, interim AD duties, and 2025 hire Scott Cochran—while maintaining competitiveness and producing NFL/CFL talent such as Malcolm Butler and Tyreek Hill.

**Keywords**:  
Bobby Wallace, Gulf South Conference, NCAA D-II playoffs, coaching transitions, NFL alumni

**Title**: West Alabama Tigers Football History

**Summary**: The West Alabama Tigers football program, established in 1931, has experienced cycles of success and decline under various coaches. Early achievements included Vaughn Mancha’s 1946 team that defeated Florida State and played in the Paper Bowl, followed by Morris Higginbotham’s 1968 Peanut Bowl appearance. Mickey Andrews led the Tigers to their only championship in 1971, while Jim King guided them to a notable 1975 NCAA playoff run. After a 15-year drought without a winning season, Bobby Wallace’s hiring in 2006 briefly revived the program with a 6–5 record in his first year, though subsequent seasons saw mixed results.

**Keywords**: West Alabama Tigers, college football history, Gulf South Conference, NCAA Division II, coaching legacy

**Title**: 1911 Alabama Crimson Tide Season  

**Summary**:  
The 1911 Alabama Crimson Tide football team, led by first-year head coach D. V. Graves, compiled a 5-2-2 record while competing in the Southern Intercollegiate Athletic Association. Standout performances included shutouts of Howard, Marion Military Institute, and Tulane, with Adrian and Hargrove Vandegraaff anchoring both offense and defense. After early wins, Alabama tied Mississippi A&M and Georgia Tech (earning praise for Hargrove from John Heisman) and suffered narrow losses to Georgia and Sewanee before rallying to defeat Davidson in the finale.  

**Keywords**:  
Alabama football, 1911 season, Vandegraaff brothers, SIAA, D. V. Graves
